editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: PRIDE entereth into thee, √¥ man, through ignorance, bicau≈øe thou knowest not thy ≈øelfe. And thus doth ignorance ingender pride; when thine owne conceit deceiueth thee, making thee beleeue, that thou art better than indeed thou art. div.p: O Man, how goodlie a creature art thou? How excellent? div.p: ALL woorthine≈ø≈øe is vnwoorthie of the verie name of woorthine≈ø≈øe, if humilitie be de≈øpi≈øed. If therefore, √¥ man, thou art in authoritie, be notwithstanding as an vnderling: if thou art a Gouernour, yet thinke not ≈øcorne of ≈øubiection.

div.p: O Man, remember thou art but du≈øt & a≈øhes, rottennes & woorms meat. Remember al≈øo, O man, that if thou art anie thing, except thou aba≈øe & humble thy ≈øelfe by ≈øo much, as thou art aboue and better than the re≈øt, thou dooe≈øt vtterlie loo≈øe what≈øoeuer thou art.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by PATIENCE or forbearance.

div.p:

Giue vs, we be≈øeech thee, better grace, that we may ≈øee into our ≈øelues, examine our owne con≈øciences, and turne-ouer the bils of dets, which thou mo≈øt fauourablie and mercifullie ha≈øt cancelled and cut in peeces, to the end that we taking thee for an example, might acquit and forgiue our brother, if there were anie thing betweene vs: and patientlie to put vp iniuries and wrongs, though the fle≈øh naturallie doo ≈øtorme therat, referring vengeance

O powre into our harts, we be≈øech thee, plentie of patience, wherof alas there is great want in this our age, as appereth by the coldnes of charitie & loue, who≈øe propertie it is to be pitifull & long-≈øuffering, to be gentle, courteous, and full of tendernes: lea≈øt being forward, irefull, rough, vnquiet, and greedie after reuengement, we heare this ≈øentence denounced again≈øt vs; Wo vnto you that haue lo≈øt patience: bicau≈øe it is a nece≈ø≈øarie vertue, and greatlie to be regarded; that after we haue done the will of thee, √¥ father, we might receiue the promi≈øe, for Ie≈øus Chri≈øts ≈øake, Amen.

div.head: The ninth Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:
LET vs watch and ward ouer all our works, lea≈øt we ouer≈ølip the dooing
of that which God commandeth, we commit that which hee forbiddeth. Let vs watch and ward ouer our words, lea≈øt in vttering them we offend God, or damnifie and hurt our neighbour. For happie is he, who in all his communication and talke hath an eie to the≈øe two feares; the fir≈øt of Gods Maie≈øtie, in who≈øe hands it is horrible to fall; the other of our brothers frailtie and weaknes, whom it is the ea≈øie≈øt thing of a thou≈øand to offend.

For ≈øo long as we abide in this earthen ve≈ø≈øell of fle≈øh & bloud, we can not be free from offences. And therefore, if thou remember that thy brother bee offended at thee, bee not waiward, but humble and lowlie to craue pardon. And if thou haue ought again≈øt him, be not malapert in controlling, nor hard to intreate; but mild in reproouing, and gentle to forgiue, and all ≈øhall be well, and at peace.

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by waiwardnes, and malapert controlling.
div.p:
O Man, is it m√©et that fools, ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe, & bruti≈øh bea≈øts ≈øhould be ≈ømoothed and ≈øoothed
with faire words? Or rather is it not more conuenient, that they ≈øhould be roughlie rebuked, and taken vp with bitter and ≈øharpe taunts, ≈øo often as they offend? For it is not mild ≈øp√©ech that can preuaile with ≈øuch as lacke iudgement and rea≈øon: and therefore to deale with them in that order, it is labour ≈øuperfluous. Take them vp as one hauing authoritie, for beare them not an inch, v≈øe ≈øuch words in reproouing them, as are agr√©eable to the maner of their dealing.

If a woman offend th√©e, beare not with hir weaknes: if an old ancient father, y√©eld nothing to his age or grauitie: if a learned Doctor, e≈øt√©eme not of his per≈øon: if thine equall, hold fowle ≈øcorne at his ≈øaw≈øines: if thine inferior and vnderling, checke him, and make him hold his tongue: if thy parents, alledge thou art no child; and ≈øo turne their controlments vpon their owne necks. Finallie, be h√©e better, or be he ba≈øer that rebuketh
thee, forbeare him not, but with ≈øtowtnes ≈øtand in defence of thy ≈øelfe.

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Eternall God, Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which ≈øee≈øt our ≈øecret & hidden thoughts, and the i≈ø≈øue of euerie enterpri≈øe, before we our ≈øelues are certaine to what end the ≈øame will growe; remooue from vs, we praie thee, all waiwardnes, & malapert controlling of our brethren for their offences. And whereas our nature is ≈øtout, rebellious, and vnpatient of reproofe; in ≈øo much that oftentimes we ≈øpurne at them that admoni≈øh vs for our amendment, and reward them, not onelie with counterchecks, but al≈øo with open wrong, & manife≈øt abu≈øe: as Ahab did Micah; Mana≈ø≈øes E≈øaie; Pa≈øhur Ieremie; Herod Iohn Bapti≈øt; and the Iewes Ie≈øus: roote out of our harts, good Lord, that
wicked cu≈øtome, and let vs not by refu≈øing correction, double our offence, and ≈øo make it the more odious.

Furthermore, mo≈øt mercifull Father, indue vs with wi≈øedome and di≈øcretion, that we may be led with the eies of vnder≈øtanding; to iudge betwixt the ≈øinner and his ≈øinne, to ob≈øerue due time & ≈øea≈øon of reprehending, to be mild & gentle in reproouing ≈øuch as be tractable, but ≈øharpe & rigorous to the ob≈øtinate & wilfull: otherwi≈øe we ≈øhall little preuaile, in labouring to ≈øupplant iniquitie, and to reforme the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor.

Teach vs the true v≈øe of that whol≈øome coun≈øell, mini≈øtred vnto vs by thy ≈øonne Chri≈øt; namelie, that if our brother tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe again≈øt vs, we go and tell him his fault priuatelie, betweene him & vs; if that will doo no good toward the winning of him home, then to put other meanes in practi≈øe, before we procure his open ≈øhame. This le≈ø≈øon
o Lord, giue vs grace to learne; and not onelie to learne, but al≈øo to remember; and not onlie to remember, but al≈øo to exerci≈øe and folowe: that the end of our labour be≈øtowed according to thy will, may tend to the glorie of thy mo≈øt holie name, the ≈øafetie of repentant ≈øinners, & the di≈øcharge of our owne con≈øcience, through Ie≈øu Chri≈øt our onlie mediator & aduocate, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: PRe≈øumption and ob≈øtinacie are the waies of diuels; flie from them, √¥ man, lea≈øt thine enimie triumph ouer thee. For in the≈øe ≈øinnes he reioiceth exceedinglie, hauing made proofe in him≈øelfe, how vnpo≈ø≈øible it is to recouer, and get out of ≈øuch a gaping gulfe.

Now I would not haue thee ignorant, √¥ man, what are the ≈øteps of this downe-fall, or breake-necke: the fir≈øt is the di≈ø≈øembling of thine owne weaknes; the ≈øecond
the ignorance of thine owne wretchednes; the third is the excu≈øing of thine owne wickednes; and the fourth is open contempt and per≈øeuering in ≈øinfulnes.

Which ≈øteps, if thou wilt not tread in, √¥ man, nor be ≈øwalowed vp in this irrecouerable whirlepoole of de≈øtruction, de≈øpi≈øe not good coun≈øell; di≈ødaine not to be rebuked; but mildlie and meekelie take warning when thou doce≈øt ami≈ø≈øe; and when thou art rebuked of ≈øinne and vngodlines, take it in good part on Gods name, and beare it patientlie with the ≈øpirit of ≈øoftnes and gentlenes.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by MEEKENES, or gentlenes.
div.p:
O Man, this per≈øua≈øion may in no ca≈øe be followed. For it is flatlie again≈øt the coun≈øell & adui≈øe of the Apo≈øtle, who admoni≈øhing his beloued ≈øcholler Timothie in this behalfe, ≈øaith: Rebuke not an elder, but exhort him as a father: the
yoonger men as brethren; the elder women as mothers; the yoonger as ≈øi≈øters, in all cha≈øtitie.

Againe, The ≈øeruant of the Lord mu≈øt not ≈øtriue, but be gentle vnto all men, apt to teach, ≈øuffering euil, in m√©ekenes in≈øtructing them that are contrarie minded. Againe, Improoue, rebuke, exhort in all long ≈øuffering and doctrine. This vice of waiwardnes, or malapert controiling, doth more hurt to the ba≈øer ≈øort, than to the better; to the ≈øubiect, than to the magi≈øtrate. For it coÃÑmeth to pa≈ø≈øe oftentimes, that they contemne correction and reprehen≈øion, v≈øed & vttered with mildnes, loue, and charitie: and again≈øt words ≈øpoken with humilitie & lowlines, they will not ≈øticke to ≈øhoote the ≈øhafts of ≈øhameles deri≈øion and ≈øcorning.

Herevpon it is thus written in Scripture: Who ≈øo reprooueth a ≈øcornefull per≈øon, getteth him≈øelfe di≈øhonour. Againe, Reprooue not a ≈øcorner, lea≈øt he owe th√©e euill will.
Contrariwi≈øe, of him which amendeth, when he is reprooued, and is the better being rebuked, it is thus ≈øpoken: Rebuke a wi≈øe man, and he will loue thee.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p: O Lord, which from time to time ha≈øt placed among thy people meete & conuenient ve≈ø≈øels to carrie the me≈ø≈øage of thy word & will, that thereby they might be in≈øtructed & taught, how damnable their ≈øtate is, during the time of their pilgrimage in wicked waies, and bypaths of impietie; and ha≈øt di≈øper≈øed and ≈øowne among vs plaine tell troth Nathans, to reprooue vs of our iniquities and ≈øinnes: giue vs grace, we be≈øeech thee, that the preaching of the one, and the reproouing of the other, may worke vpon vs, like new made waxe, apt to receiue anie fa≈øhion or forme.

O plant in vs a patient ≈øpirit,
which may make vs lowlie in hart; and reformable in will; that the words of the admoni≈øher may not pa≈ø≈øe by vs like a ≈øudden bla≈øt of wind, but rather worke effectuallie in our harts, euen like fire, which fineth ≈øiluer by the vertue of his heate. Remooue from vs all rebellious motions of the fle≈øh, which are euer again≈øt the good ≈øugge≈øtions of the ≈øpirit: & direct vs in the waie of wi≈øedome, that we may take and choo≈øe what≈øoeuer is whol≈øome for vs, yea though the ta≈øte thereof be as bitter as woormewood to the mouth of our carnall man.

We knowe, √¥ Father, that to purge abundance of corrupt humours, which ingender euill di≈øea≈øes, the phy≈øician mini≈øtreth bitter pils: & to an old ≈øore, which can not be cured with a gentle pla≈øter, the ≈øurgeon applieth a biting cor≈øiue: which medicines, though to the patient mo≈øt greeuous and painfull; yet in con≈øideration that they are preparatiues to health, they are receiued,
well taken, and ≈øuffered. And therefore √¥ Lord vouch≈øafe vs the grace of thy holie ≈øpirit, wherby we being guided, conducted, and gouerned, may not murmur at the admonitions, reprehen≈øions, and corrections of our brethren, though they rebukes vs ≈øharpelie: but may mo≈øt thankefullie take their reproofes, knowing that the end and ≈øcope of their labour ≈øo imploied, is for the edification of our ≈øoules in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, to whom be prai≈øe for euermore, Amen.

div.head: The tenth Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:
SWelling loftines is a ≈øelfe-liking of ones owne excellencie, and hath attending vpon hir two waiting maids broken to hir owne bowe, the one is blind pride; the other vaine pride: whereof the fir≈øt is a fault of the vnder≈øtanding, the ≈øecond of
the will. For by that, the eie of rea≈øon is deceiued; and by this, the de≈øire of will abu≈øed.
Blind pride maketh a man beleeue he is better than he is; whereby he ≈øwelleth in the opinion of his owne excellencie, boa≈øting of him≈øelfe, and giuing no glorie at all vnto God.

Vaine pride bewitcheth a man in ≈øuch ≈øort, that he braggeth, not onelie in that which he hath, but in that which he hath not; and is more delighted in his owne commendation, than in the prai≈øe of God. But why ≈øwelle≈øt thou, √¥ dirt and doong? Why art thou loftie? All fle≈øh is gra≈ø≈øe, and all the glorie thereof as the flowre of haie. He that planteth is nothing, nor he that watereth. What ha≈øt thou that thou ha≈øt not receiued, and why then art thou ≈øo loftie?

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by ≈øwelling LOFTINES.
div.p:
O Man, if thou haue anie bu≈øines to doo, anie affaires in the world to deale in, anie matter
wherin to meddle, to it with a good ≈øtomach, and feare not the face or looking on of anie maner of per≈øon. Followe thine owne coun≈øell and determination. For, another mans wit is not ≈øo good, but thine may be much better.

And therefore aba≈øe not thy ≈øelfe, but compare with the be≈øt. Let not thine opinion and iudgement b√©e ≈øchooled by anothers adui≈øe and con≈øultation. What ≈øhoulde≈øt thou ≈øubmit thy ≈øelfe to the cen≈øure of men? Ha≈øt thou not God in heauen an eie-witnes and ouers√©er of thy dealings? Why then ≈øhoulde≈øt thou care, what men ≈øu≈øpect and mi≈ød√©eme of th√©e in earth?

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Mercifull God, ca≈øt the light of thy countenance vpon vs, which are nothing but mi≈øt & darknes, that the ≈øame ≈øhining vpon vs, may illuminate vs outwardlie and
inwardlie, to the ≈øanctifieng both of our ≈øoules and bodies, which thou ha≈øt created to ≈øet foorth the glorie of thy mo≈øt holie name.

And bicau≈øe, good God, there are manie conueiances of vices in our harts, and manie holes and corners for ≈øinnes of ≈øundrie ≈øorts to lurke in, the lea≈øt wherof de≈øerueth death and condemnation: we mo≈øt humblie craue of thy diuine Maie≈øtie, that it would plea≈øe thee to cru≈øh out of our entrailes, as out of a ≈øponge, all ≈øuch filthie and ≈øtinking defilings, as haue, euer ≈øince the daie of our natiuities, lien there ≈øoking and ≈øoupling, to the vtter putrifieng & con≈øuming both of ≈øoule and bodie.

Speciallie mo≈øt mercifull Father, be vnto vs ≈øo good a phy≈øician, as to mini≈øter but one dram or ≈øcruple of thy grace, that ≈øwallowing the ≈øame downe into the ≈øtomach of our ≈øoules, we may vomit and ≈øpue out all ≈øwelling loftines, which puffeth vs vp like wind blowne into a bladder.
O heale vs thou mo≈øt carefull and cunning leach of mankinde, which knowe≈øt, and onelie vnder≈øtande≈øt what maladies are incident to this our mortalitie, & with what medicines they are to be expelled.

Suffer not ≈øo dangerous an humor to abound in vs, lea≈øt ouer-ruling vs, it preuaile, and carrie vs as it li≈øt, from woor≈øe to woor≈øe, till we be brought at la≈øt euen to the gates of hell: as Nemroth, Nabuchodoni≈øor, Pharao, Antiochus, Herod, & the re≈øt of that ambitious & proud race were, euen at the verie ripenes of their pompe, when they thought all things ≈øafe and in perfect ≈øecuritie. Wee craue it ≈øo much the more in≈øtantlie, √¥ Father, bicau≈øe thou ha≈øt threatened to ca≈øt downe the high mountains, and to make them eeuen with the lowe plaines: to lop the tall ceders of Libanus, and to make them equall with the ba≈øe bulru≈øh: that thou onelie maie≈øt be honoured in thine
excellencie, and that all creatures ≈øtooping vnto thee, may do homage and reuerence to thee their Creator. Humble me, √¥ Lord, in this maner, and pull downe the pinacles of my proud hart, that my ≈øoule may be made a man≈øion for thy Maie≈øtie to dwell in, thy Sonne to abide in, and the holie Gho≈øt to continue in: to whom be all honour and power for euermore, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: FOlowe after me, ≈øaith Chri≈øt, pa≈ø≈øe through me, drawe neere to me: after me, bicau≈øe I am the truth; through me, bicau≈øe I am the waie; to me, bicau≈øe I am the life. Againe he ≈øaith, Who ≈øo will come after me, let him denie him≈øelfe, take vp his cro≈ø≈øe, and followe me.

Wherein he laieth three things before vs, bondage, ba≈øenes, & hardnes. Bondage in denieng him≈øelfe, ba≈øenes in taking vp the cro≈ø≈øe, hardnes in following Chri≈øt;
who≈øe life was tempered with no kind of worldlie plea≈øure.

By this we are taught to humble our ≈øelues, and to be lowlie in our owne eies; to be reformed when we are rebuked; and not to hold ≈øcorne of correction, when we are blame-woorthie. For the waie to be perfect, is to learne how to amend that which is vnperfect: if we neglect this, we ≈øhall neuer come to that.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by humble LOWLINES.
div.p:
O Man, thou mu≈øt giue no occa≈øion of ≈ølander, or euill ≈øpeaking, no ≈øu≈øpicion of priuie whi≈øpering & ≈øecret talking: but if thou be guiltie of ≈øuch faults, as thou art charged withall, confe≈ø≈øe them, that thou maie≈øt amend when thou art rebuked: if not, denie them with humble lowlines, and cl√©ere thy ≈øelfe by the true prote≈øtation of an vpright con≈øcience: bicau≈øe the Apo≈øtle admoni≈øheth th√©e, that thou
oughte≈øt not to giue anie occa≈øion to the aduer≈øarie of ≈øpeaking ≈ølanderou≈ølie.

Which thing the Apo≈øtle dete≈øted euen in them, that knowing the Chri≈øtian faith, ≈øat downe notwith≈øtanding to eate meates offered vnto idols. And although they e≈øt√©emed an idol as a toie, or a thing of naught: yet, taking vnto them, and ta≈øting idolatrous meates, as altogither harmeles, and nothing at all offen≈øiue, they did tie the weake con≈øciences of their vn≈øtaied brethren, to the damnable rites and ceremonies of idols, by this their euill and vnchri≈øtian d√©ed.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p:
O Almightie & euerla≈øting God, which from the beginning of the world, ha≈øt throwne the thunderbolts of thy iu≈øtice and vengeance at ≈øuch, as ob≈øtinatelie haue continued in their ≈øinne, without
remor≈øe of con≈øcience, or feare of thy iudgements; we mo≈øt humblie be≈øeech thee, to heare the praiers of vs thy ≈øeruants, and to grant the petition of our lips. O deliuer vs not ouer into the rule of Satan our gho≈øtlie enimie, lea≈øt he make a ≈øpoile of our ≈øoules, and feede on them, as a falcon vpon a dooue, or as a woolfe vpon a lambe.

Be thou the gouernor of our life, and the directer of all our deeds, that we may walke in the waies of thy lawe, and tread the paths of thy coÃÑmandements: out of which when we wander and go a≈øtraie, neglecting the conduction and leading of thy grace, we fall into the temptation of the diuell, and beecome outca≈øts from the Commonwealth of I≈ørael, exiles and outlawes from the te≈øtament of the couenant, and haue our names ≈øcraped out of the regi≈øter booke of euerla≈øting life.

Let vs intreate thee therefore, √¥ mo≈øt mercifull God, by the mediation and interce≈ø≈øion of thy Sonne
our Sauiour, to giue vs that which we a≈øke, euen an humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of mind, which working in vs effectuallie, may ≈øtrike downe all kind of in≈øolencie, hawtines, vaineglorie, ambition, arrogancie, and what≈øoeuer el≈øe dooth hinder vs froÃÑ entering into thy heauenlie kingdome.

We knowe, √¥ Father, the commodities depending vpon this ble≈ø≈øing, to be not onlie ≈øingular, but al≈øo manifold. For when we offend, it worketh in vs an inward ≈øorowe for ≈øinne, a greefe for di≈øhonor done to thy Maie≈øtie, a care of con≈øcience, a purpo≈øe to amend, and a de≈øire to be reconciled. When we are rebuked, it maketh vs take warning gladlie, thinke vpon our offence ≈øadlie, lament the ≈øame earne≈øtlie, repent in hartilie, craue pardon vnfeignedlie, and walke euer after more circum≈øpectlie: through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our onelie mediator and aduocate, Amen.

div.head: The third Section, and eleuenth Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice. in≈øuing.
div.p: HEAVINES is bred in mans hart ≈øundrie waies; and is an affection naturallie graffed therein, not blameable, if it be meaurable; but offen≈øiue, if it be exce≈ø≈øiue. And therefore to torment thy ≈øelfe with too much ≈øorowe, and to refu≈øe comfort for the lo≈ø≈øe of things temporall, which come and go like the tide, is extreame madnes. Awaie with that worldlie and vngodlie ≈øorowe; for God hath no plea≈øure therein. If thou wilt knowe what ≈øorowe plea≈øeth the Lord, I tell thee it is ≈øorowe for ≈øinne, which is ingendred of repentance, & begetteth righteou≈ønes.

The remedie again≈øt this ≈øorowe, that it breake not beyond the bounds of moderation, and ≈øo degenerate into de≈øpaire, is Gods vn≈øpeakable mercie; euen his mercie,
which is aboue all his works. As for heauines, procured by the variable ≈øtate of the world, and the inconueniences belonging to this life; e≈øteeme of them, √¥ man, as they are, outward cha≈øti≈øements and ≈øchool-points to traine thee to amendement.

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by vngodlie SOROWE, or HEAVINES
div.p:
O Man, thou ha≈øt manie occa≈øions to b√©e heauie and ≈øad, and nothing in the world whereat to reioice or be merrie. Not ≈øo much as thy neighbours and friends, but are wearie of th√©e; thine acquaintance haue for≈øaken th√©e, and thou ha≈øt a weightier burden of cares and ≈øorowes, than thou art able to beare. Con≈øider thine owne heauines & angui≈øh, by viewing of other in the like ca≈øe: imagine what hanging lookes, what lamentable countenances, what hollowe eies, what
thin ch√©ekes they haue, whom the pa≈ø≈øions of ≈øorrowes and cares doo oppre≈ø≈øe.

In this perplexitie, where is thy comfort, where is thy con≈øolation, thy lightnes of hart, and mirth of mind? It were much better for th√©e to for≈øake all, and to die, that the≈øe torments might cea≈øe: than enioieng life, to ≈øuffer a continuall increa≈øe of ≈øuch core≈øiue and eating cares. For he, whom gr√©efe and heauines hath ≈øwallowed vp, receiuing no delight in anie vi≈øible thing, mu≈øt n√©edes looke for a lamentable end.

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Eternall God, in who≈øe power it is to make the weake ≈øtrong, the ≈øicke ≈øound, the poore rich, and the heauie merrie: we knowe, and by experience haue fealt this to be true, that di≈øordinate heauines hindereth that which is good, and maketh
entrance vnto that which is euill. And therefore the wi≈øe mans adui≈øe is woorthie, not onelie to be learned, but al≈øo to be followed: namelie, not to giue our minds to heauines, nor to vexe our ≈øelues in our owne coun≈øell. For as the ioie of the hart is the life of man, and his gladnes the prolonging of his daies; euen ≈øo ≈øorrowe is his death, and heauines ≈øhorteneth his time.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p:

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by godlie reioicing, and ≈øpirituall COMFORT.
div.p: O Man, I knowe that of heauines there are two kinds, the one worketh to ≈øaluation, the other to damnation: the one draweth to repentance, the other to de≈øperation. Thou art a≈ø≈øaulted with one of them, not with that which worketh vnto life, but with that which worketh vnto death. Thou mai≈øt not be ≈øad and heauie, in ≈øuch ≈øort as thou art per≈øuaded; but contrariwi≈øe, if thy ≈øorowe and heauines ≈øpring from ≈øome externall cau≈øe, as for that art enuied and hated for the truths ≈øake, thou oughte≈øt to reioice in the≈øe thy gr√©efes?

And why? Bicau≈øe thou not knowing to what i≈ø≈øue they will growe, art notwith≈øtanding to be comforted by the voice of the giuer of euerla≈øting ioie & gladnes,
≈øpeaking thus vnto th√©e: Ble≈ø≈øed are you, when men ≈øhall reuile you, and per≈øecute you, and lieng ≈øhall ≈øay all maner of euil ≈øaieng again≈øt you for my ≈øake. Reioice ye, and be glad, for great is your reward in heauen.

Remember al≈øo, O man, that the Apo≈øtles, the fore-runners of this religion, departed from the face of the Councell, reioicing that they were counted woorthie to ≈øuffer ≈øhame and reproch for the name of Ie≈øus. If thy ≈øorowe and angui≈øh, O man, proc√©ed from the remor≈øe of con≈øcience for thy ≈øinnes, remember a multitude of offenders, that by repentance haue obteined mercie at Gods hands, according to the truth of his promi≈øe: In what daie ≈øoeuer a ≈øinner dooth repent him of his ≈øinne and wickednes, I will put all his iniquitie out of
my remembrance, ≈øaith the Lord. Againe, Though thy ≈øinnes were as red as ≈økarlet, yet will I make them as white as wooll: & though they were as filthie as the men≈øtruous cloth of a woman, yet will I make them as white as ≈ønowe.

Remember, O man, the mercifull Semaritan in the Go≈øpell, that powred wine and oile into the ≈øicke mans wounds, ≈øet him on his owne a≈ø≈øe, brought him to an inne, and paid for his nece≈ø≈øaries. If thy heauines, O man, proc√©ed from the con≈øideration of thy poore e≈øtate, from the remembrance of thy lo≈ø≈øes by ≈øea or land, from vnthankfulnes of affinitie and kindred, from frowardnes of children, from wilfulnes of wife, from vnfaithfulnes of ≈øeruants, learne patience of Iob: The Lord giueth, and the Lord taketh awaie, euen as it ple≈øeth the Lord, ≈øo let things come to pa≈ø≈øe.

Learne of thy Sauiour Chri≈øt to ≈øubmit thy will to Gods will, and to ≈øaie: Thy will be done in earth, as it is in heauen. Thus arming th√©e with ≈øpirituall furniture, thou ≈øhalt not be heauie either to de≈øperation or damnation, but ≈øorowfull to repentance and amendement, and ≈øo con≈øequentlie thou ≈øhalt find ioie and comfort.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p: O Bountifull God, the Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who≈øe eies of mercie and louing kindnes are alwaies open, and broad waking ouer thy ≈øeruants, ouer≈øeeing them, that none inconuenience or euill thing inuade them; not the arrowes of the hunter at noone-day, nor the dangers of the darts of darknes at mid-night; we be≈øeech thee of thine infinite goodnes and clemencie, to continue thy fatherlie affection and fauour at all times, ≈øpeciallie in the time of per≈øecution, trouble ≈øorowe, need, and aduer≈øitie, that we may not waxe heauie-hatred in our tribulations; but reioice rather and be glad, per≈øuading our ≈øelues, that by the fire of afflictions thou trie≈øt thy children like ≈øiluer, and fine≈øt them, that they may be made fit and woorthie coine to receiue the ≈øtampe of their Creator and King.

Giue vs patience, good Lord, to ≈øuffer what≈øoeuer it ≈øhall plea≈øe thy heauenlie wi≈øedome to laie vpon our ≈øhoulders; according to the example of thy ≈øeruant Iob, who e≈øcaping no kind of aduer≈øitie that might happen to the bodie of man, his ≈øtate, condition, credit, and abilitie, did not reuile thee, nor yet cur≈øe thee to thy face, although he was greeuou≈ølie tempted of Satan by thy permi≈ø≈øion, and ≈øorelie a≈ø≈øalted of his wicked wife, to renounce thee his maker, and ≈øo to end his mi≈øerable life; but ble≈ø≈øed and prai≈øed thy diuine Maie≈øtie, ≈øuppo≈øing it nece≈ø≈øarie to receiue euill at thine hands, as well as good.

Euen ≈øo, √¥ eternall God, and mo≈øt mercifull Father, if it be thy will at anie time to cha≈øti≈øe vs, either with ≈øicknes, pouertie, or anie other kind of aduer≈øitie, vouch≈øafe therewithall to arme vs with contentation of mind, quietnes of con≈øcience, and con≈øolation of ≈øpirit, that we may be ≈øo far from being di≈øcomforted in

div.head: The twelfe Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by ≈ølothfull IDLENES.
div.p:
O Man, art thou called to be a churchman, and to liue deuoutlie in praieng or reading? I wi≈øh th√©e

div.p:

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: THis is the ≈øumme of vertuous & ≈øpirituall exerci≈øe; this is the forme of godlie endeuour; wi≈øelie to di≈øpo≈øe and order things pre≈øent, penitentlie and in the bitternes of thy ≈øoule to con≈øider thy mi≈ødeeds pa≈øt, and carefullie to prouide and fore-≈øee things to come.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by hone≈øt and vertuous EXERCISE.
div.p:
O Man, prolong no time, neither driue off from daie to daie, but whiles thou ha≈øt ≈øpace doo thine indeuour to liue hone≈øtlie, painfullie, vertuou≈ølie, and deuoutlie. div.p:
O Almightie & euerla≈øting God, who ha≈øt placed vs in this world for two ≈øpeciall ends and

div.head: The xiij. Combat.

div.p: O Holie ≈øoule, be ≈øolitarie and alone, that thou maist ≈øerue him onelie, and keepe thy ≈øelfe for him alone, of whom thou hast made thy ≈øpeciall choi≈øe aboue all other. div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by wandering loo≈øe LIBERTIE.
div.p: O Man, con≈øider with thy ≈øelfe that thou art a creature borne to libertie, and not to ≈øeruice: let thy mind therefore run vpon choi≈øe and varietie; tie it not to one ≈øpeciall place, or one proper practi≈øe. div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Lord God, Father of light, we giue thee mo≈øt hartie thanks for thy great loue and clemencie declared vnto vs, in ≈øtopping the ≈øwift cour≈øe, which thou by thy diuine

Let this, √¥ Lord, be a ≈øufficient warning vnto vs, that by libertie there commeth more euill than good: naie, rather no good at all. What the cau≈øe ≈øhould be of ≈øo

Turne our harts, √¥ Lord, that we affect not, couet not, de≈øire not this dete≈øtable libertie, which though to the fle≈øh, and the wild lu≈øts of the ≈øame, it be delectable and plea≈øant;
yet to the ≈øoule it is mo≈øt damnable and noi≈øome. Deliuer vs from it, √¥ Lord, for it is the nur≈øe of vanities: √¥ deliuer vs from it for thy mercie ≈øake, and for thy beloued ≈øonnes ≈øake, our Sauiour and redeemer Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: THere is nothing more vnstable and wauering, nothing more ≈øwift and flitting in thee, √¥ man, than thine owne hart, which ≈øo often as it ≈øtumbleth at the ≈øtone of euill thoughts, ≈øo often it offendeth God. Thy hart is vaine, variable, and vn≈øearchable; and ≈øo often as it is led by it owne will and con≈øent, ≈øo often it wanteth Gods coun≈øell. It is like a bird flieng out of hir nest, like a ≈øhip lanching into the deepe, like an arrowe ≈øhot out of a bowe. And what is the cau≈øe of this vn≈øtablenes? euen lacke of trust in God.

Trust in God, √¥ man, and continue in thy place; beleeue in him, affie thy ≈øelfe on
his goodnes, and thou ≈øhalt obtaine contented ≈øtaiednes. A foole changeth and altereth like the moone, but a wi≈øe man abideth firme and fast like the ≈øunne: a foole wauereth like a reede, but a wi≈øe man ≈øtandeth ≈øtill like a ≈øtrong oke: a foole is compared to the wandering ≈øtarres, which are euer moouing; but a wi≈øe man is likened to the fixed ≈øtarres, which keepe their appointed places. For the first the mi≈øt of darknes is prepared; for the ≈øecond the cleerenes of light is ordeined.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by Chri≈øtian contentment, and STAIEDNES.
div.p:
O Man, if the ca≈øe ≈øtand as thou ≈øaie≈øt, and confe≈ø≈øe≈øt, that God is eueriewhere, then is it thy dutie to k√©epe th√©e where thou art, and not to for≈øake that place, which thou woulde≈øt ≈øo faine change for another: bicau≈øe God is in it, by his greatnes, which filleth euery place. But thou wilt ≈øaie, O man, I
≈øeeke for a better, and I find a better. But I an≈øwere th√©e, and ≈øaie thus againe vnto th√©e with boldnes and truth: Thou ≈ø√©eke≈øt a better place, but dooe≈øt thou find a better, or ≈øuch a one as thou knowe≈øt Lucifer and Adam lo≈øt?

Remember therefore that the fir≈øt angel fell from heauen, and the fir≈øt man was bani≈øhed out of paradi≈øe, & became acquainted with the troubles of this world. Looke vpon Lot, who liuing among the thicke≈øt of the bea≈øtlie Sodomites, and ≈ø√©eing their filthie behauiours, remained holie notwith≈øtanding & vndefiled: but when he came to dwell in the mountaine, and had growne hard in ≈øecuritie, he became drunke, and fell into the filthines of ince≈øt with his owne daughters.

Marke al≈øo, O man, what mi≈øchiefs followed loo≈øe libertie in Dina the daughter of Iacob, who not contended to tarrie at home, but de≈øiring to ≈ø√©e fine fa≈øhions abroad,

There is be≈øide this kind of loo≈øe libertie, another licentious wandering, which worketh in the minds euen of ≈øuch as k√©epe them≈øelues in one place, and withdraweth their harts from ≈øpirituall exerci≈øes, intangling them in affaires of the world, or el≈øe finding them occupied in mo≈øt vile and homelie things, contrarie to the coun≈øell of the Apo≈øtle in this ca≈øe, who ≈øaith: No man that warreth, intangleth him≈øelfe with the affaires of this life, that he may plea≈øe him, which hath cho≈øen him to be a ≈øouldiour. And againe, Praie without cea≈øing, in all things giue thanks.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p: O Euerla≈øting GOD, the well≈øpring of all true wi≈ødome and vnder≈øtanding, who≈øe will & plea≈øure it is, that we ≈øhould walke in obedience before thee all the daies of our life, brideling the vanities of our minds, the ranging lu≈øts of our fle≈øh, the concupi≈øcence of our eies, and what≈øoeuer is at enimitie and variance with thee: we be≈øeech thee to beate downe in vs all wild and vn≈øtaied affections, which wre≈øtle again≈øt the ≈øpirit, & hinder vs from dooing that homage vnto thy diuine Maie≈øtie, which we are inioined by the verdict of thy mo≈øt holie word.

And bicau≈øe experience teacheth vs, that no ≈ømall mi≈øchiefe ari≈øeth and ≈øpringeth from loo≈øe libertie, whiles we not content with our natiue countrie cu≈øtome, hunt after not onelie foren fa≈øhions in outward
maners, but al≈øo new deui≈øed opinions in doctrine and beleefe: wee be≈øeech thee tie our harts in one vnitie of faith, as there is but one truth of thy Go≈øpell: and expell and driue out of our minds all de≈øire of licentiou≈ønes, which is the match to ≈øet on fire the powder of fanta≈øticalnes.

O let vs not ≈øtraie about to Dan and Bethel, ≈øuffer vs not to go on pilgrimage to Babylon and Rome: but let thy grace be a ≈ønaffle in our mouth, to keepe vs within the wals of holie Ieru≈øalem, there to wor≈øhip thee in thy ≈øanctuarie in ≈øpirit and veritie. And as we craue an vniformitie in matters of religion, ≈øo Lord we be≈øeech thee, to make vs of one mind in maners and behauiour, to be content with a reuerent and mode≈øt v≈øe of thy creatures, and not to abu≈øe them to the fulfilling of our owne vaine imaginations.

Of our ≈øelues we are like wandering weather cocks, as vncertaine as the wind, as variable as the weather,
as mooueable as the ≈øea: now inclined to this vanitie, now to that fantasie, neuer ≈øtedfa≈øt, but euer changable: and therefore, good Lord, open our vnder≈øtanding, that we may ≈øee how irregularlie & out of rule we walke: and ≈øeeing it, may be a≈øhamed; & being a≈øhamed, may be greeued, and being greeued, may ≈øeeke to be reformed; euen by thy ≈øpirit of con≈øtancie, which is able to worke in vs a continuall and immutable per≈øeuerance, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord, Amen.

div.head: The xiiij. Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:
DESPERATION breedeth a ripenes, fulnes, and perfection of all ≈øinne. De≈øperation commeth by the ignorance of God. If the ignorance of God haue hold of vs, how doo we beleeue in him, how doo we hope in him, how doo we trust in him, of whom we are ignorant? We knowe al≈øo,
that ≈øuch as are de≈øperate, haue no part or follow≈øhip with the Saints.

But how doth the ignorance of God ingender de≈øperation? Some man peraduenture comming home to him≈øelfe, being di≈øcontented, and di≈øplea≈øed at the euill deeds which he hath done, and purpo≈øing to repent, and turne backe from all his euill waies, and carnall conuer≈øation; if he be ignorant how good God is, how ≈øweete, how gentle, and how fauourable to forgiue; will not his con≈øcience choked with fle≈øhlie thoughts, reprooue him, and ≈øaie, What doo≈øt thou man? wilt thou loo≈øe not onlie this life pre≈øent, but al≈øo the life to come?

Thy ≈øinnes are exceeding great, and too too manie, ≈øo that it is far aboue thy reach to make amends for them anie waie: no, if thou wouldest flea thy ≈øelfe, and pull thy skin ouer thine eares; thou art not able to acquit thy ≈øelfe. Thy fle≈øh is tender and nice, thy life hath beene delicate & wanton, ≈øo that it will be an hard matter for thee to ouer-maister custome.

At the≈øe and the like ≈øpeeches, or ≈øuggestions, the de≈øperate ≈øoule ≈øtarts backewrapped
in wo, being vtterlie ignorant how ea≈øilie the goodnes of almightie God, who will not the death of a ≈øinner, can remedie all this: wherevpon followeth impenitence, which is an heinous ≈øinne, and bla≈øphemie vnpardonable.

Then the ≈øeelie ≈øoule troubled in mind, and ≈øore di≈øquieted, is ≈øwalowed vp with an extreame heauines of hart, and is carried headlong into ≈øo deepe a gulfe of inward angui≈øh, as he can not po≈ø≈øiblie recouer him≈øelfe, by the ministerie of anie comfort: or el≈øe di≈ø≈øembling the matter, and flattering him≈øelfe, how wicked ≈øoeuer he be, with likelie rea≈øons, and plea≈øant per≈øua≈øions, he betaketh him≈øelfe afre≈øh to the world, enioieng all the delights and vanities of the ≈øame, with full purpo≈øe neuer to be withdrawne from it by anie meanes.

Now when he ≈øaith, peace and quietnes, all is well, and without danger; then, euen then ≈øudden destruction ≈øhall ouertake him, as a woman with child, and he ≈øhall not e≈øcape. Thus then of the ignorance of God, commeth the fulnes of all iniquitie, which is de≈øperation.

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by diueli≈øh DESPERATION.
div.p: O Man, how heinous be the ≈øinnes which thou ha≈øt coÃÑmitted? How gr√©euous, how accur≈øed, how abhominable, how deadlie, how damnable? Thine offences are ≈øo manie, that they can not be numbered; and ≈øo great, that they may not be pardoned. Thou ha≈øt continued a tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor all thy life long, and ha≈øt not to this daie once thought vpon amendement.

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Eternall God, and Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which ha≈øt planted vs in thy vineyard, to ≈øhoot forth our branches, and yeeld

And bicau≈øe, √¥ Lord, it is thy nature and propertie to abhor ≈øinne, little or much, con≈øidering the integritie and perfection of thy diuinitie, which is commended in Scripture to be ≈øuch, that the verie heauens are counted vncleane in thy ≈øight: grant vnto vs ≈øuch light of true knowledge and vnder≈øtanding, that therby we may be lead as by a bright burning lampe, out of the darke lanes of ignorance, wilfulnes, ob≈øtinacie, peruer≈øenes, and ≈øuch like.

E≈øpeciallie deliuer vs from falling

O Lord, pre≈øerue and keepe vs, during the time of our nauigation in the ≈øeas of this trouble≈øome life; lea≈øt thou, who art the Pilot of the pinne≈ø≈øe, wherein thy people pa≈ø≈øe through the narrowe ≈øtreights of death, withholding thy hand, and

Defend vs from ≈ølipping into the pit of perdition with Iudas, that child of wrath and de≈øtruction: √¥ ≈øaue and re≈øcue vs, good Lord; tender vs as the apple of thine eies: and from all ≈øinne, but cheefelie from de≈øperation deliuer vs, and our po≈øteritie, from generation to generation, for Ie≈øus Chri≈øts ≈øake, our onlie mediator and aduocate, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p:
THere is a place betweene feare and carele≈ønes, namelie, hope, the golden meane, wherein mans mind and con≈øcience ≈øleepeth most ≈øweetlie vpon the ≈øoft bed of loue, vnderlaid with patience. A ≈øweete cau≈øe, verie effectuall, pithie, and pa≈øt reuoking. Not to di≈øappoint them that hope in him, is a most comfortable reward, a rich gift, a bountifull large≈ø≈øe. For God refu≈øeth not to be the hope of the mi≈øerable, bicau≈øe he is mercifull: he di≈ødaineth not to ≈øhew him≈øelfe a deliuerer, but he will be a protector and defender al≈øo of them that hope in him.

Behold man, reckon vp thy tribulations by number, his con≈øolations ≈øhall make glad thy ≈øoule; if thou turne not to other by-helpes, if thou crie out vnto him, if thou hope onlie in him. For in all temptation, in all vexation, in all time of nece≈ø≈øitie, the citie of refuge is readie to receiue vs, the bo≈øome of the Father is wide open for vs, the holes of the ≈øurest rocke doo gape for vs to run into, the bowels of Gods bottomles mercie are our ≈øanctuarie to franchi≈øe vs.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by faithfull HOPE.
div.p: O Man, if thy ≈øinnes and offences come to reckoning, behold the de≈øcription of Dauid, who being guiltie of adulterie and man-≈ølaughter, was notwith≈øtanding, through the mercie of God, deliuered from the mouth of hell. Looke vpon Marie Magdalen, plaieng the common ≈øtrumpet, and defiling the ve≈ø≈øel of hir bodie with innumerable fornications: but afterwards better adui≈øed, ≈øhe came with ≈øorowe and angui≈øh of mind to the fountaine of godlines, and wa≈øhing the Lords f√©ete with hir teares, ≈øhe wiped them with hir hairie locks, ki≈ø≈øed, licked, and annointed them with ointment: by which hir humilitie ≈øhe ta≈øted the
≈øw√©etnes of Gods mercie, and obteined remi≈ø≈øion of hir ≈øinnes.

Looke al≈øo vpon Peter, who by denieng his leege Lord & mai≈øter, tangled him≈øelfe in the cords of vnbel√©efe; but afterwards touched with remor≈øe of con≈øcience for ≈øo dooing, hee did vntie the knots of tho≈øe cords of infidelitie, with bitter teares and hart gr√©efe.

Looke vpon Saule per≈øecuting the congregation of God, breathing out threatenings afre≈øh again≈øt the flocke of Chri≈øt, and imbruing his hands with the bloud of the martyrs: of a per≈øecuter, became a preacher; of an apo≈øtata, an apo≈øtle; & of a va≈ø≈øall to ≈øin, a ve≈ø≈øell

S√©eing therfore, O man, ≈øo manie examples of penitent ≈øinners before thy face, let not wicked ≈øp√©eches make place for de≈øperation to enter into thine hart, con≈øidering it is thus written in holie Scripture: In what daie ≈øoeuer a ≈øinner dooth turne and for≈øake his ≈øinnes, being ≈øorie for them from the bottome of his hart, he ≈øhall be ≈øaued. And againe, I will not the death of a ≈øinner, ≈øaith the Lord.

As touching conuer≈øation of life ≈øtill wickedlie continued, and not changed from the wor≈øe to the better, what ≈øhould I ≈øaie but this; that the thing which a man neglecteth to doo to day, let him be carefull to doo to morowe, whiles he hath life in him, and time to repent and amend.

Let him not prolong and driue it off from daie to daie; but hauing helpe of God from heauen, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted with the ≈øpirit of ≈øanctification, let him doo his endeuour dailie
to with≈øtand the euill cu≈øtome of ≈øinne, and let him ≈øay with the prophet euerie morning and euening: Behold, I haue now begun; the right hand of the Highe≈øt hath wrought this alteration & change.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p: O Pitifull Samaritan, which did≈øt ≈øo lament our di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ca≈øe, when wee were wounded with the inuenomed darts of ≈øinne, that thou vouch≈øafed≈øt to heale vs, euen by applieng the mo≈øt comfortable pla≈øters of thy hart bloud to our de≈øperate ≈øores: √¥ heare the praier and ≈øupplication which wee powre out before thy mercie-≈øeat; be≈øeeching thee of thine accu≈øtomed kindnes, √¥ louing Io≈øeph, to make vs rich in vertue & godlines: ≈øpeciallie, bring our harts into the ≈øafe rode & harbour of hope, where lieng at re≈øt, they can take no harme.

And although our ≈øinnes, like hie

And bicau≈øe hope is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie, √¥ ≈øweete Sauiour, that without it we cannot be ≈øaued, knowing that it is one of the vertues, which mu≈øt aduance & prefer vs vnto thee, (for in faith, hope, and charitie, con≈øi≈øteth the obteining of perfect felicitie) we be≈øeech thy goodnes to ≈øtabli≈øh

Thou being ≈øo gratious and fauourable vnto vs, it can not be, but that in all tempe≈øts of trouble≈øome thoughts, raging in vs through the ≈øting of our ≈øinnes, and bringing vs out of quiet; we ≈øhall pre≈øentlie apprehend thy promi≈øe, encouraged by a liuelie hope; and running from wickednes, as from the ruine of a rotten wall, be erected, ≈øupported, and vnderpropped with the firme foundation of thy faithfulnes, which neuer faile≈øt the con≈øtant beleeuer, tru≈øting to thy word, and building thervpon, as vpon a mo≈øt firme and vn≈øhakeable foundation: but performe≈øt the vttermo≈øt of thy couenant, euen to the third and fourth generation of them that loue thee, and keepe thy commandements: which to ob≈øerue, and liue thereafter,

div.p:

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p:
THE deceitfull pompe of this world is de≈øeruedlie refu≈øed, and the glorie thereof woorthilie de≈øpi≈øed. It is the floure of haie; & a ≈ømoke that lasteth but a while. The best ≈øtate thereof, what≈øoeuer it be, dooth it not bring more angui≈øh and vexation, than plea≈øure or delectation? Whiles, √¥ man, thou purcha≈øest, whiles thou v≈øurpest, whiles thou defendest, whiles thou maintainest, whiles thou

If there be anie, the plea≈øure thereof pa≈ø≈øeth awaie, and is neuer like to returne to thee; but the griefe and angui≈øh thereof abideth, and is neuer like to leaue thee. Neuertheles, thou maist ≈øee that manie lacke it, and few ≈øet light by it: why? trulie bicau≈øe need is in manie, and vertue in few.

O wicked world, which art woont ≈øo to ble≈ø≈øe and pre≈øerue thy friends, that thou makest them Gods enimies; and con≈øequentlie, vnfit for the felow≈øhip of Saints! For doubtles, he that will be thy friend, is made Gods enimie: and therfore a friend of the world, is ≈øhut out from the companie of Gods friends. When the ≈øpirit is once tasted, the fle≈øh must needs loo≈øe his ≈øauour; to him that hungreth after heauenlie things, earthlie things are not tooth≈øome; to him that longeth for eternall things, tran≈øitorie things are loth≈øome. O ye ≈øonnes of Adam, ye couetous and ambitious generation; giue eare and marke. What haue you to doo with earthlie riches, and temporall glorie, which indeed are no true riches, nor yours to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe? The ≈øhortnes of the world is certaine; but the end of the ≈øhortnes thereof is vncertaine: oftentimes they for≈øake the liuing, and commonlie folowe the dead. The plea≈øure, the delight, and comfort of the world is ba≈øe, vile beggerlie, and good for nothing: yea rather (a thing much to be feared) it is a blocke or let to true and whol≈øome comfort. For what is there in this life, but labour and trauell, griefe, angui≈øh, and vexation of mind?

Thou wouldest faine eate, bicau≈øe hunger

In this ca≈øe are all things vnder the ≈øunne, ≈øo that nothing is plea≈øant or comfortable in verie deed: but man will pa≈ø≈øe from one to another, to be releeued by change. For the remedie of one labour or paine, is the beginning of another. There is no wicked per≈øon in this world, that can haue what he will. The righteous man can not be ≈øati≈øfied with righteou≈ønes; the v ‚Ä¢ luptuous man with voluptuou≈ønes; the curious man with curiou≈ønes; the ambitious and vaine-glorious man with vain-glorie.

But wo be to them, that hunt after vaine and flitting glorie. For whiles they ≈øeeke to haue ioie and delight in tran≈øitorie things, that ioie and delight can not but pa≈ø≈øe awaie, with the verie things them≈øelues whereof they ≈øpring. For as fire faileth, when wood is wanting; ≈øo vani≈øheth

Let the worldling therefore ≈øee and vnder≈øtand; let him marke and con≈øider; bicau≈øe the end of his ioie is mourning and lamentation. div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by the CONTEMPT of this WORLD.
div.p:
O Man, the≈øe things are not brought to pa≈ø≈øe of worldlings, without great danger and offence; bicau≈øe the more a man hath, the more he coueteth: ≈øo that he hath no mea≈øure in his de≈øires, whiles he maketh ha≈øte to become a verie ≈øeruant or ≈ølaue to innumerable cares of this life. Our Sauiour Chri≈øt al≈øo, ≈ø√©eing what mi≈øch√©efe it is, would not in anie ca≈øe ≈øcale vp ≈øuch a ≈øinne in

Againe, It is ea≈øier for a camel to pa≈ø≈øe through the eie of a n√©edle, than for a richman to enter into the kingdome of heauen. If therefore couetou≈ønes in the harts of worldlings, be ≈øuch a plaguie and pe≈øtilent infection: what ≈øhall we think thereof, if it be found in them that haue taken their fare-well of the world, and bequeathed them≈øelues wholie to the Lord? Be y√©e not carefull (≈øaith our Sauiour) what ye ≈øhall eate, or what ye ≈øhall drink, or what ye ≈øhall weare. For after all the≈øe things doo the Gentiles ≈ø√©eke. But fir≈øt ≈ø√©eke the kingdome of God, and the righteou≈ønes therof, and all the≈øe things ≈øhall be giuen you. O ble≈ø≈øed lsaeing, void of

But thou wilt ≈øaie peraduenture, O man, It is requi≈øite that religious and godlie men ≈øhould haue more in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion (riches I meane, and other vten≈øiles) than other priuate hou≈øholders, con≈øidering that they be≈øtowe them better, than the common people, in rel√©euing the poore & n√©edie members of Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, and ≈øuch like works of charitie. The nature of this di≈øea≈øe of cocouetou≈ønes

div.p: O Eternall and immortall God, we be≈øeech thee, that the life of thy deerlie beloued ≈øonne, and his di≈øciples, during the time of their ≈øoiourning in this earth, the verie inne of iniquitie, may be prouocations vnto vs, to ≈øpend the remnant of our flitting age in ≈øinglenes of hart, innocencie, and all vertuous conuer≈øations: that hauing before our eies ≈øuch liuelie examples of godlines, we may declare in our deeds a fruitfull imitation of them before the face of all men.

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by hardnes of hart, or VNCHARITABLENES.
div.p:

div.p: O Mo≈øt tender & louing Father, we mo≈øt humblie be≈øeech thee, that we remembring the words of thine apo≈øtle S. Paule, to wit, What≈øoeuer is written, is written for our learning, may ca≈øt the eies of our memorie vpon the mounting ≈øins of Sodom, which were pride, fulnes of bread, abundance of idlenes, and contempt of the poore: and being terrified with thy heauie iudgment powred out of a full viall of thy vengeance, euen to their vtter de≈øolation and con≈øuming with fire and brim≈øtone, may hate and dete≈øt to the death, all kind of iniquitie, e≈øpeciallie the ≈øinne of vncharitablenes, again≈øt the which thou art ≈øo mortall an enimie, as thou art a neere friend to mercie.

O giue vs not ouer to the inordinate lu≈øts and de≈øires of our owne depraued nature, which is more
prone to bring foorth ranke and venemous weeds, than good & whol≈øome herbs. And let the bright morning ≈øtar of thy grace ≈øo ≈øhoote his beames of light into our mi≈øtie minds, that all filthie fogs of affections di≈øper≈øed and driuen awaie; vncharitablenes likewi≈øe, with the re≈øt, may be di≈øplaced, throwne out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and troden vnder feet: con≈øidering that ≈øo long as we giue ≈øo graceles a ge≈øt hou≈øe-roome in our harts, we can not be touched with compa≈ø≈øion of the poore: being void of compa≈ø≈øion, wee contemne the poore: contemning them we ≈øtop our eares at their crie: ≈øtopping our eares, we ≈øhut the bowels of pitie again≈øt them: ≈øhutting the bowels of pitie, what doo wee but murther them mo≈øt mi≈øerablie?

The end and reward of which merciles intreating of the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, being ouergrowne with vncharitablenes, is, when we make our mone vnto thee, √¥ Lord, not to be heard: and when we ≈øeeke ≈øuccour,
to be ≈øent awaie emptie: √¥ giue vs grace to waxe fearfull at the example of the vncharitable rich man, who≈øe want of pitie purcha≈øed vnto him ≈øtore of endles torments: heare vs for Chri≈øts ≈øake, and from all vncharitablene≈ø≈øe defend vs and our children, to the third and fourth generation, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: MERCIE is an affection, which is neither re≈øtrained by will, nor ≈øubdued to rea≈øon; bicau≈øe euerie bodie dooth not drawe it to him≈øelfe voluntarilie at his owne plea≈øure: but mercie mooueth godlie minds with a nece≈ø≈øarie affection to haue compa≈ø≈øion of the ≈øad, ≈øorowfull, grieued, and distre≈ø≈øed per≈øon; in ≈øo much that although it were a ≈øinne to be mercifull; doo as much as I might, and what my will forceth me vnto, yet I can not choo≈øe but be mercifull.

Rea≈øon and will may indeed pull backe
≈øomewhat from this affection, they may hinder it a little, but are they able to root it out of the hart, to ≈øupplant it, to quench it? Iustice requireth de≈øert, but mercie beholdeth mi≈øerie. True mercie iudgeth not, but taketh pitie; it ≈øtandeth not vpon examining, but is content with the pre≈øent occa≈øion. For rea≈øon is not looked for, where affection draweth. For the mind, which loue hath once raui≈øhed, and compa≈ø≈øion pricked, is not ≈øuffered to haue rule ouer it ≈øelfe. It feareth things which it knoweth not, greeueth at things which behoue not, is more carefull than it would be, and for cau≈øes that it ≈øhould not be: vnwilling it ≈øuffereth, vnwilling it pitieth.

Some are mercifull in re≈øpect of things not belonging vnto them; and the≈øe are offended, bicau≈øe men giue not abundantlie to all; howbeit in ≈øuch ≈øort, that they them≈øelues in that modicum or little of theirs are not touched with remor≈øe; who if they were mercifull, then ought they to ≈øhew mercie by giuing their owne; and if they be not able of their worldlie mucke, yet ≈øhould they with a good will pardon
≈øuch as haue offended them, they ≈øhould giue ≈øweet dole, euen a good word, which is the best gift that can be giuen, that their minds may be mooued to repentance. To conclude, they ≈øhould not onlie haue pitie, but al≈øo praie for all ≈øuch as they knowe are in ≈øinne; otherwi≈øe, their mercie is no mercie, and therefore they ≈øhall not obtaine mercie.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by COMPASSION and MERCIE.
div.p:
O Man, if thou k√©epe that mea≈øure in this re≈øpect of giuing, which the Apo≈øtle dooth pre≈øcribe, thou maie≈øt both be≈øtowe vpon the impotent, and al≈øo haue ≈øufficient for the maintenance of thy familie. And therefore to this purpo≈øe the Apo≈øtle v≈øeth a pithie ≈øp√©ech, verie apt and conuenient, ≈øaieng: If there be a willing mind, it is accepted according to that which a man hath; & not according to that
which he hath not.

Not that other be ≈øet at ea≈øe, and you burthened: but of like condition now at this time, your abundance ≈øupplieth their want, that their abundance al≈øo may ≈øupplie your want, that there may be an equalitie, as it is written: He that had gathered much, had nothing ouer: and he that had gathered little, had no lacke.

Herevpon a certaine righteous father admoni≈øheth his vertuous ≈øonne in this ≈øort: If thou ha≈øt much, giue plentifullie; but if thou ha≈øt little, giue al≈øo of that little willinglie. To the ≈øame effect al≈øo the word incarnate (Ie≈øus Chri≈øt I meane) ≈øaith thus: But rather giue almes of tho≈øe things which you haue, and behold, all things are cleane vnto you. Li≈øten furthermore, O man, what the ≈øcripture ≈øaith: He ≈øhall haue iudgment without mercie, which ≈øheweth no mercie.

To the contrarie whereof, the
prophet v≈øeth the≈øe words, Breake thy bread to the hungrie, and bring the poore and harbourles into thy hou≈øe. When thou ≈ø√©e≈øt one naked, couer him, and de≈øpi≈øe not thine owne fle≈øh. Remember what heauie doome happened to the rich man in purple and ≈øilke, who was not condemned bicau≈øe h√©e tooke from other men their owne goods: but for that h√©e gaue not of his plentie & abundance to the n√©edie.

Was he not tormented in hell, and forced there to make euen verie ≈ømall reque≈øts, and yet could not obtaine them; bicau≈øe whiles he liued in this life, he denied trifles to the ≈øuccouries? He denied the little crums falling from his table, and therefore it was not granted vnto him to haue the tip of his tongue cooled with cold water. He would not ≈øend his ≈øeruants with a little refre≈øhing to the poore beggar; and therefore he could not get ≈øo much grace, as to let his brethren vnder≈øtand his torments for their in≈øtruction
and amendement.

But marke, O man, the ≈øeuere ≈øentence of the iu≈øt Iudge, denounced and thundered out in wrath and vengeance again≈øt the wicked goats on his left hand: Go ye cur≈øed into euerla≈øting fire, prepared for the diuell and his angels. For I was hungrie, and you gaue m√©e no meate: and ≈øo foorth, as followeth in that place verie iu≈øtlie and terriblie.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p:
O Eternall and gratious GOD, who by ≈øeuere reuengement executed vpon the vnmerciful, ha≈øt commended vnto vs the contrarie vertue; we mo≈øt humblie be≈øeech thee, that the diuine admonition of thy ≈øonne, that pitifull Samaritane, who ca≈øt his eies of compa≈ø≈øion vpon the wounded traueller, lieng in the high waie betweene Ieru≈øalem and Iericho, after that a prie≈øt and

And bicau≈øe the ≈øacred Scripture teacheth vs: that With what mea≈øure we meate vnto others, the like they ≈øhall meate vnto vs againe: vouch≈øafe that we learning and folowing the ≈øage and ≈øound coun≈øell of Salomon, may di≈øtribute our temporall riches liberallie with open hand; knowing that we ≈øhall be recompen≈øed with plentie: and may water abundantlie, beleeuing that we ≈øhalbe rewarded with ≈øtore of ≈øea≈øonable raine: that is, for mercie, to receiue mercie, which thou require≈øt rather than ≈øacrifice.

Let the examples of thy ≈øeruants, and that principallie of Dauid, a man according to thine owne harts de≈øire, direct vs to the full di≈øcharge of our dutie; who although he had
opportunitie to kill Saule, and was thereto incited by the adui≈øe of his warriers, had compa≈ø≈øion of him notwith≈øtanding, refu≈øing to laie his hand vpon the Lords annointed. Euen ≈øo, good & gratious God, grant vs to deale with our enimies, that although they per≈øecute vs mo≈øt tyrannicallie, and mo≈øt villanou≈ølie intreate vs; yet we may put vp all iniuries patientlie, praieng for their amendment, and referring vengeance vnto thee, who≈øe it is by proper challenge.

Finallie, mo≈øt bountifull Father, what gift ≈øoeuer thou ha≈øt be≈øtowed vpon vs, be it either wi≈ødome, coun≈øell, vtterance, knowledge of tongs, or other ornament of mind what≈øoeuer, which anie of our brethren wanting, may by the imparting and v≈øing thereof reape ≈øome profit; vouch≈øafe vs, that we may be ≈øo far from denieng them our helpe and ≈øuccour; that we may be well content to let all that we po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe bee conuerted and turned into their
benefit: ≈øo far foorth, as ≈øafetie of con≈øcience will ≈øuffer, and thy glorie allow. This grant, √¥ good God, for Ie≈øus ≈øake, our onelie mediator and aduocate, Amen.

div.head: The xvij. Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:
CRaftie and deceitfull dealing, commonlie called cou≈øenage, is to be abhorred for three notable rea≈øons: first, bicau≈øe it offendeth Gods Maiestie heinou≈ølie, in ≈øo much that Salomon ≈øaith, It is an abhomination to the Lord, Secondlie, bicau≈øe it defraudeth and beguileth a mans neighbour with a ≈øhew of honest meaning; against which default Dauid complaineth, ≈øaieng: Their throte is an open graue, they deceiue with their tongs, the poi≈øon of a≈øpes is vnder their lips: againe, They haue made their words ≈øofter than oile, but indeed they are ≈øharpe arrowes. Thirdlie, bicau≈øe the deceiuer is

As for theft, we ought to flie from it, as from a ≈øcorpion, and that for three ≈øpeciall rea≈øons: first, bicau≈øe God forbiddeth vs, ≈øaieng; Thou ≈øhalt not ≈øteale. Secondlie, bicau≈øe of the danger depending thervpon, taught vs in the≈øe words: He that taketh part with a theefe, hateth his owne ≈øoule. Thirdlie, bicau≈øe of the puni≈øhment belonging therevnto; namelie, three-fold and foure-fold restitution, according to the lawe Leuiticall: and lo≈ø≈øe of life by the ≈øentence of the po≈øitiue lawes of ≈øundrie countries, be≈øides the plague of al plagues in the world to come, fore-told by the mouth of the Apostle, that Theeues ≈øhall haue no portion in the kingdome of God. Where then? Euen in hell fire, the kingdome of the blacke prince of darknes.

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by craftie collu≈øion, deceitfull dealing, and theft.
div.p: O Man, ob≈øerue the cour≈øe of the time, and con≈øider, that as euerie one is bent to ≈ø√©eke for his owne aduantage; ≈øo is it for th√©e likewi≈øe to v≈øe the ≈øame libertie. Art thou called to be ≈øome noble, ≈øome wor≈øhipfull, ≈øome rich mans ≈øteward, ≈øecretarie, chamberline, bailie, or ≈øurueier? v≈øe thy place in ≈øuch ≈øort, as thou mai≈øt gaine extraordinarilie be≈øides thy wage≈ø.

Art thou in office in citie or countrie? Di≈ø≈øemble the faultes of them that are wealthie for rewards: and be not too ≈øeuere in the execution of lawes and penall ≈øtatutes. For it is commonlie ≈ø√©ene, that the be≈øt Iu≈øticiarie is not be≈øt beloued: but he that can winke at the offences of ≈øuch as are of countenance, h√©e carrieth

Art thou an artificer, an occupier, a merchant, or of anie kind of trade? I coun≈øell th√©e then to make thy wares, though they be ≈øtarke naught, ≈ø√©eme exceeding pure and good: be it ≈øilke, veluet, cloth, or anie other vten≈øile, cau≈øe and procure them to be ≈ølightiie wrought, that although the price of them be verie hie, yet they may ≈øoone fret out, weare awaie, and doo little ≈øeruice.

Art thou a mai≈øter, and ha≈øt a retinue of ≈øeruants to maintaine thine occupieng? V≈øe their ≈øtocks to thy benefit, and defraud them of ≈øome part or parcell thereof, vpon ≈øome craftie deui≈øe of charging them with vntruth & di≈øhone≈øtie in their ≈øeruice. A thou≈øand ≈øubtilties there be, O man, which thou maie≈øt v≈øe with ≈øafetie of con≈øcience, to the inriching of thy ≈øelfe, if thou wilt marke the trade of the world.

of thy hands, a keeper of companie, and ha≈øt b√©ene brought vp all thy life time, in dooing nothing towards the getting of thy liuing? I will teach th√©e how to ≈øhift, and maintaine thy ≈øelfe like a Gentleman. S√©eke acquaintance of ≈øuch as v≈øe the ≈øea, and learne to be ≈økilfull in nauigation: when thou art become expert therein, put this into the heads of thy confederates, to practi≈øe piracie: for that is a thing which manie haue venturou≈ølie taken in hand, and in ≈øhort ≈øpace growne maruellous rich.

It that faile th√©e, and can not be ≈øo conuenientlie compa≈ø≈øed, thou ≈øhalt find enow to take thy part on land, with whom thou maie≈øt ioine in ≈øocietie, & get manie a good bootie. Doo this, and I warrant th√©e lacke no liuing.

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Almightie God, for≈øomuch as it is thy heauenlie will and diuine
plea≈øure, that we ≈øhould like louing and obedient children, like relenting and bux≈øome creatures, imitate and followe thee in holines and purenes of life (which we are ≈øure then mo≈øt ≈øpeciallie to doo, when with our vttermo≈øt indeuour, we applie our ≈øelues in thought, word and deed, to ob≈øerue thy commandements) purge our affections, we praie thee, and trie them ≈øeuentie ≈øeuen times by the purifieng fire of thy ≈øanctifieng ≈øpirit.

We knowe this for a truth, that except we re≈øemble thee in qualitie, according to thy ≈øonne our Sauiours admonition, exhorting vs to be perfect and holie, as thou our father art perfect & holie; there is no hope that we ≈øhall attaine to that incorruptible fruit of our heauenlie calling. And therefore, good Lord, let thy grace burne brightlie before vs, like a lampe repleni≈øhed with fre≈øh oile; that we ≈øeeing our waie, may ≈øo order our ≈øteps in this trouble≈øome trauell of ours in this
wicked world, as thou thereby mai≈øt be magnified.

The verie in≈øtinct of nature teacheth vs, √¥ Lord, be≈øides thy commandement, which bindeth vs, that we ≈øhould doo to our brethren, as we would they ≈øhould doo vnto vs: that no man ≈øhould abu≈øe the grace of his calling, by craftie circumuention to procure his priuate profit, or by anie ≈øini≈øter and indirect dealing, to the detriment and hinderance of another, (a fault too too common in this our age) but that contrariwi≈øe, we ≈øhould beare one anothers burden in charitie, and Chri≈øtian brotherhood.

Which lawe of nature neuertheles, being neglected; and thy precept, tending to the ≈øame effect, not regarded: we be≈øeech thee notwith≈øtanding, to winke awhile at the follie of men, to beare with their infirmities, and to mealt their fro≈øen harts with the thawing heate of thy feruent ≈øpirit; that being a≈øhamed of abu≈øing their vocation, and
trembling at thy di≈øplea≈øure, they may praie for grace to amend all that is ami≈ø≈øe, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord and Sauiour, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: WILT thou learne, √¥ man, how to v≈øe true and plaine dealing? I will tell thee what thou must doo. First ≈øee to thine inward eie, that it be ≈øingle indeed, whereto I thinke two things verie nece≈ø≈øarie; namelie, charitie in the intent, and truth in making thy choi≈øe. For if thou loue that which is good, and choo≈øe not that which is true, thou hast a zeale of God, but not according to knowledge: and I wot not how in the iudgement of truth, plaine dealing, and double dealing may ≈øtand togither.

Christ the truth it ≈øelfe, being di≈øpo≈øed to traine his di≈øciples to true plaine dealing, willeth them to be wi≈øe like ≈øerpents, and harmeles as dooues. He ≈øetteth wi≈øedome before plaine dealing, without
the which he knew well inough none could be a true plaine dealer. How then ≈øhall the eie be ≈øingle indeed, with the ignorance of truth? It is euident therefore, that this prai≈øe-woorthie plaine dealing, commended of Chri≈øt, is not without the≈øe two good properties: namelie, well willing, and wi≈øedome; that the eie (to wit) of the hart, might not onlie be godlie, and ≈øo vtterlie vnwilling to deceiue; but al≈øo warie, as not able to be deceiued.

Furthermore, as the≈øe two properties make the eie ≈øingle; namelie, the loue of that which is good, and the knowledge of that which is true: euen ≈øo the≈øe two contraries make the eie euill, to wit, blindnes, or ignorance, which hindereth the knowledge of the truth: and frowardnes or wilfulnes, which cau≈øeth a man to loue iniquitie and wickednes.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by VPRIGHTNES, and plaine dealing.
div.p:
O Man, it is much better to be poore, and not able to giue anie thing at all, than
to indamage or hurt thy freend, thy neighbour, or thy brother by robberie or ≈øubtiltie. For he which vniu≈øtlie taketh awaie another mans goods, and liueth vpon the ≈øpoile, he ≈øhutteth the gates of the kingdome of heauen again≈øt him≈øelfe.

H√©erevpon, that profound Preacher of the Gentiles reprooueth certaine of the Corinthians his hearers, ≈øaieng: There is vtterlie a fault among you, becau≈øe you go to lawe one with another. Why rather do ye not put vp wrong? Why rather doo y√©e not ≈øuffer harme? Nay, y√©e your ≈øelues doo wrong, and doo harme, and that to your br√©ethren. Knowe ye not that the vnrighteous ≈øhall not inherit the kingdome of God?

The ≈øame Apo≈øtle reckoning vp a rabble of filthie ≈øinners, that are excluded from comming to Gods kingdom, addeth the≈øe in the number, ≈øaieng: Neither th√©eus nor extortioners ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the kingdome of heauen. Againe, in another
place, by waie of exhortation, he teacheth th√©e a le≈ø≈øon, O man, which if thou wilt learne, it ≈øhall doo th√©e great good, namelie: that what≈øoeuer things are true, what≈øoeuer things are hone≈øt, what≈øoeuer things are iu≈øt, what≈øoeuer things are pure, what≈øoeuer things pertaine to loue, what≈øoeuer things are of hone≈øt report, tho≈øe things doo; and the God of peace ≈øhall be with th√©e.

This God of peace preci≈øelie forbiddeth theft, ≈øaieng: Thou ≈øhalt not ≈øteale. And Chri≈øt Ie≈øus the ≈øauiour of thy ≈øoule ≈øpeaketh thus vnto th√©e: Loue thy neighbour as thy ≈øelfe. To the ≈øame effect the Apo≈øtle giueth th√©e coun≈øell to put off the old man with his works; in the number wherof, euill concupi≈øcence & couetou≈ønes are reckoned.

The la≈øt precept giuen in that place, is to doo that hartilie which we doo, as vnto God, not to men; wherevpon he inferreth this ≈øentence: He that doeth wrong, ≈øhall
receiue for the wrong which he hath done. The ≈øame Apo≈øtle giueth this whole≈øome adui≈øe to the Colo≈ø≈øians: To doo their owne bu≈øines, and to worke with their own hands, that they might walke hone≈øtlie, and lacke nothing.

To conclude, if thou art commanded, O man, to ab≈øteine euen from the verie appearance of euill; iudge with thy ≈øelfe, and examine thine owne con≈øcience, whether it be lawfull for th√©e, either craftilie to circumuent, or violentlie to ≈øpoile thy Chri≈øtian brother. Remember the la≈øt commandement: Thou ≈øhalt not couet that which is anothers, then learne to be contented with thine owne.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p:
O Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the liuelie and expre≈ø≈øe image of the Father; for≈øomuch as it is a le≈ø≈øon taught vs in thy Go≈øpell, that we ≈øhould be
≈øimple as dooues, louing as lambs, and innocent as little children, otherwi≈øe we can not enter into the kingdome of heauen: we be≈øeech thee by thy bitter death and pa≈ø≈øion, to root out of our cankered and corrupt minds, all maner of euill concupi≈øcences, which like ranke weedes ouergrowe and choake all kind of good and godlie affections in vs; ≈øo that we can not thinke, much le≈ø≈øe doo that, which is acceptable to thy diuine plea≈øure.

May it plea≈øe thee therefore, √¥ Lambe of God, that take≈øt awaie the ≈øinnes of the world, for thy bloudie wounds ≈øake, wherein my faults, and the offences of all mankind were buried, to plant in vs, and in euerie one of vs, a childi≈øh and infant-like innocencie, whereby we may vtterlie forget the fal≈øehoods & ≈øubtilties of wicked worldlings, wherein they are ≈øo deeplie grounded, that they make no con≈øcience of anie profered iniurie, of anie violent extortion, of anie diueli≈øh oppre≈ø≈øion,

div.p:

div.head: The xx. Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by fooli≈øh and exce≈ø≈øiue REIOICING.
div.p: O Man, con≈øider with thy ≈øelfe, that there is no part or member of thy bodie, but ≈øerueth to ≈øome end; the eare to heare, the eie to ≈ø√©e, the tongue to ta≈øte, the no≈øe to ≈ømell, the fingers to f√©ele, the throte to ≈øwallowe, the ≈øtomach to dige≈øt, the ≈øecret parts to ingender, the legs and f√©et to carrie the bodie from place to place, and the hart principallie to perceiue, thinke, vnder≈øtand, deui≈øe, and meditate vpon ≈øundrie matters.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: SOROWE is of two ≈øorts, good and bad; both which are no le≈ø≈øe di≈øcernable by their effects, than the tree by the fruite. div.p:

div.head: The fift Section, and 21. Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p: WHO is able to number the great enormities, which the tongue, a verie little member, doth procure? Who can tell how manie times double the filthines and vncleannes is, which lieth thickened and tempered in vncircumci≈øed lips? div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p:

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by di≈øcreet SILENCE.
div.p:

div.head: The xxiij. Combat.

div.p: O Man, neuer ca≈øt this ≈øtumbling-blocke before thy con≈øcience, that leacherie is a deadlie ≈øin, and de≈øerueth damnation. But the creator him≈øelfe would not prohibit or forbid th√©e, O man, the plea≈øure of the fle≈øh in carnall copulation, which a companie of dizzards call the ≈øin of leacherie, when in d√©ed it is no ≈øin; bicau≈øe it beginneth with loue, and endeth with repentance: and therefore why ≈øhould anie one be≈øide him, attempt to per≈øwade, or exhort th√©e to the contrarie?

div.p:

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p: VN≈øpotted CHASTITIE is the onlie iewell, which in this mortall life repre≈øenteth vnto vs a certaine ≈øtate of eternall glorie. div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by vn≈øpotted CHASTITIE.
div.p:

To conclude therfore, I put th√©e in memorie of the ≈øentence of S. Iohn, de≈øcribing the holie citie of God, new Ieru≈øalem, and the glorie of the ≈øame, into the which he affirmeth flatlie, nothing that is vncleane ≈øhall enter: for without

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p:

div.head: The xxiiij. Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p: WHOORDOME of the hart, or inward fornication is nothing el≈øe but concupi≈øcence, which bu≈øieth the mind with vnlawfull de≈øires, and poi≈øoneth all the lims of the bodie with venemous baits. div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by inward fornication, or whoredome of the hart.
div.p: O Man, if thou ha≈øt anie light of rea≈øon, any ≈øparke of iudgement & vnder≈øtanding, tell me this in con≈øcience and truth; if h√©e that con≈øenteth to lu≈øt in his heart, and committeth not the actuall d√©ed of concupi≈øcence, offend in ≈øuch ≈øort as to de≈øerue damnation? For, where action is hindered by occa≈øion of ≈øome circum≈øtance,

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p:
