hart is; then con≈øider the contrarie, that by the vilenes of the one, thou maist learne the excellencie of the other. It is naturallie graffed in euerie rea≈øonable creature, to fan≈øie the best things, and ≈øtill to couet more, though he haue enough: yea, ≈øuppo≈øe that what≈øoeuer he hath, be pure and good; yet ≈øo rauenous are his de≈øires, and ≈øo in≈øatiable his hart, that he thinketh better of other mens, than his owne. For doubtles it is a thing vnpo≈ø≈øible, to tedder & tie in concupi≈øcence, or to appoint it much or little, till it be ≈øati≈øfied, till it be filled, till it haue got wherewith to be contented. As for example. He that hath a faire wife, wi≈øheth a fairer in his hart, and is bewitched with a wanton eie. He that goeth gorgeous and gaie, ≈øetteth his mind vpon costlier and brauer attire. He that ≈øwimmeth in wealth, hunteth after more, repining at him that is richer. The moniemonger will neuer ≈øaie, I haue enough. The whooremonger will neuer ≈øaie, I haue enough. The bloud-thirstie murtherer will neuer ≈øaie, I haue enough. The ambitious vain-glorious man will neuer ≈øaie, I haue enough: and ≈øo of the rest.

What is the cau≈øe of this in≈øatiablenes, which hath no end, which hath no botome? Euen an vncleane hart, a corrupt hart, a defiled hart, an vnchast hart, which runneth a whoring after other mens goods, & will in no wi≈øe be content with his owne. A cleane & pure hart is the dwelling-hou≈øe of Chri≈øt. In ≈øuch a hart rea≈øon is ≈øo far froÃÑ error, that it agreeth with mans will. For mans will loueth ≈øuch a rea≈øon, and ≈øuch a rea≈øon mans will. Let thy will be void of vncleannes, bicau≈øe right rea≈øon alloweth ≈øuch a will.

Cleannes of hart cau≈øeth quietnes of con≈øcience. For if the hart be chast, the con≈øcience is not troubled; bicau≈øe ≈øuch chastitie and cleannes is a mortifieng of the earthlie members, a taming, a bringing downe, and a keeping vnder of corrupt affections, which are the torches that ≈øet the towe of euill deeds on fire. To the cleane harted, ble≈ø≈øednes is promi≈øed; to the vncleane harted, cur≈øednes is threatened: the one ≈øhall dwell in the Lords tabernacle; the other in the diuels dungeon: the one ≈øhall rest in Gods holie hill; the other in the vallie of death: the
one ≈øhall liue with the Lambe euerla≈øtinglie; bicau≈øe they are chast virgins: the other with the Gote (Satan I meane) bicau≈øe they are ranke harlots.

div.head: 2 The REPVLSE giuen by inward CHASTITIE, or vndefilednes of heart.
div.p: O Man, thou art a greuous offender, if thou k√©epe not the cha≈øtitie and virginitie of thy ≈øoule. For marke what the author of perfection, innocencie, and cleannes vttereth in the Go≈øpell; Who≈øoeuer (≈øaith he) looketh vpon a woman to lu≈øt after hir, he hath committed fornication with hir alreadie in his heart.

To the contrarie whereof, that patient man Iob hath this ≈øp√©ech; I haue made a couenant with mine eies, that I ≈øhould not ≈øo much as thinke vpon a woman. For how great a portion ≈øhall I haue of God from aboue, and what
inheritance of the almightie from on high? Is not de≈øtruction prepared for the wicked, and ≈øome ≈øtrange thing for the workers of iniquitie?

Furthermore, if there were not deadlie danger, euen in concupi≈øcence of the eie and the heart, it is not like that he would haue bur≈øt out with vehemencie into the≈øe ≈øp√©eches; If mine heart hath walked after mine eies, if it hath b√©ene deceiued by a woman, or if I haue laid wait at my neighbours dore, then let my wife grind vnto another man, and let other men lie with hir.

It is good for th√©e therefore to haue the petition of the Prophet Dauid alwaies fre≈øh in memorie: O Lord turne awaie mine eie≈ø, that they behold not vanitie. Embrace the whole≈øome coun≈øell of wi≈øe Salomon, Lu≈øt not after a womans beautie in thine heart, lea≈øt thou be taken with hir faire lookes.

Moreouer, if it were not ≈øo, that the verie thought of con≈øenting to wickednes did not di≈øplea≈øe the Lord thy Creator, this ≈øentence of the Prophet E≈øaie had neuer b√©en vttered; Awaie with the euill and wickednes of your thoughts from my ≈øight. Againe in the Go≈øpell, the Lord v≈øeth the≈øe words to the Phari≈øies; why doo ye thinke euill in your hearts? Neither would the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle S. Paule haue ≈øpoken in this manner; Their thoughts accusing or excu≈øing one another, at the day when God ≈øhall iudge the ≈øecrets of men, according to my Go≈øpell.

Among manie vices, which Ie≈øus the ≈øon of Sirach reciteth, exhorting vs therwithall to be a≈øhamed of them, he omitteth not looking vpon another mans wife, v≈øing manie trifling words with a maiden, or ≈øtanding by hir bed-≈øide; becau≈øe they be as it were ladders to clime vp to greater mi≈øchiefs, and therefore ought mo≈øt adui≈øedlie
to be ≈øhunned.

To knit vp my meaning in breuitie, O man, I would haue th√©e walke after the example of Chri≈øt in holines and innocencie, not deluding thine owne ≈øoule with anie fal≈øe and lieng per≈øua≈øion of the diuels ≈øugge≈øting; as though it were the actuall d√©ed, which di≈øplea≈øed Gods maie≈øtie, and that thy thoughts and cogitations are not to be called to a reckoning.

I tell th√©e, O man, that as the ≈øunne ouer-looketh all things with his cl√©erenes; ≈øo the Lord ≈ø√©eth into the verie ≈øecrets of thy heart. No thought may e≈øcape him, no imagination be hidden from him, no word be vnknowne to him, neither anie d√©ed, though neuer ≈øo clo≈øelie wrought, flie from before his face.

How then can≈øt thou deceiue him, who will not be deceiued? Or how dare≈øt thou conceiue, that thou ha≈øt ≈øhifts to ouer-≈øhoote the Lord, before whome thy heart and reines ≈øtand ≈øtarke naked and di≈øcouered?
Beware therefore, O man, of inward lu≈øting; for euen therby thou falle≈øt into the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion of the lawe, and (if Gods mercie doo not reforme th√©e) ≈øtande≈øt in ≈øtate of damnation.

div.head: 3 A praier for the former vertue.
div.p:
O Almightie & euerla≈øting God, we fall on our faces at the feet of thy Maie≈øtie, before whom our harts are as bright as gla≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that thou ≈øee≈øt euen the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øpot & ≈øtaine of the ≈øame, much more the great blemi≈øhes, which are not to be hidden; be≈øeeching thee, that whereas we haue ≈øtarted like broken bowes, from the fealtie whereto we ≈øware; and haue mo≈øt lewdlie and loo≈øelie followed the libertie of our lu≈øts, committing again≈øt thee ≈øuch ≈øinne and iniquitie, as thy ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle S. Paule admoni≈øhed vs ought not once to bee named among vs; to pardon that
is pa≈øt, and to accept our pre≈øent humiliation and repentance, in token of a full purpo≈øe to lead a godlie and reformed life hereafter.

Which that we may the better doo, for that of our≈øelues we cannot ≈øo much as conceiue one good thought; much le≈ø≈øe vtter one good word, or exerci≈øe one good deed; we craue at thy bountifull hands an vtter rooting out and ≈øupplanting of all concupi≈øcence in vs, wherby we are drawne to ≈øinne, as it were with cartropes, and intangled therein as flies in a ≈øpiders cobweb. O kill all vncleannes in vs, quench it quite, put out the heate thereof vtterlie by the working of thy ≈øpirit; that being purged within from all pollu≈øion & filthines, we may become new creatures, addicted to the true ≈øeruice of thee, and enamored with the glorie of thy name.

Sowe in vs mo≈øt plentifullie the ≈øeed of a cleane hart, which may fo≈øter and cheri≈øh with the heate therof godly & Chri≈øtian thoughts,
holie & hone≈øt affections, pure and vndefiled con≈øultations, that the fountaine and well-head of our nature being void of vncleannes, all the appurtenances of the ≈øame may be cleane and vn≈øtained: remembring the ≈øaieng of Chri≈øt our Sauiour, that nothing defileth a man, but that which breaketh out of a man; meaning the hart, which is a trea≈øurie of things good and bad. This grace, and all other graces nece≈ø≈øarie, be≈øtowe vpon vs for thine infinite mercie ≈øake, √¥ almightie and euerla≈øting God, Amen.

div.head: The xxv. and la≈øt Combat.
1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vice in≈øuing.
div.p:
TO loue this world is a double madnes; first, bicau≈øe it is variable and deceitfull: ≈øecondlie, bicau≈øe it is but the place of our pilgrimage. This world pa≈ø≈øeth
awaie, and the glorie of the ≈øame dieth in a moment: therefore to loue this pre≈øent world is a varitie of vanities. this world & the glory of the ≈øame, is like a ≈øtar, which glittereth in the firmament, and with a ≈øudden glan≈øe loo≈øeth his light. It is like a ≈øparke of fire, which is quicklie quenched and turned to a≈øhes, and therefore to loue this world, or the pomps thereof, is a woonderfull follie.

Con≈øider thine owne ≈øtate, √¥ man, the mi≈øeries therevpon depending, and the vncertaintie of thy be≈øt ioies, the ≈øhortnes of thy life, and the vnknowne comming of death: con≈øider the≈øe things well and throughlie, ≈øo ≈øhalt thou ≈øoone ≈øee in what a phren≈øie he is that loueth the world. Tell me, I praie thee √¥ man, what is become of all the louers of this world that liued in former ages? There is nothing left of them but dust, a≈øhes, and woormes meate. Weigh well what they haue beene, and what they are, euen men as thou art. They haue eaten and dronke, they haue laughed and made merrie, they haue enioied all the plea≈øures of this world, they haue ≈øpent their life-time in peace and hartsea≈øe,
but what is befallen them now?

Are they not gone to their long home, euen their graue, in the verie twinkling of an eie, waiting for a ≈øecond doome, much more terrible by a thou≈øand degrees, than this temporall iudgement, that hath pa≈ø≈øed vpon them? What doth vaine-glorie auaile, flitting ioies profit, worldlie pompe warrant, fle≈øhlie plea≈øure, delight, deceitfull riches helpe, great kindred comfort in ≈øuch a ca≈øe; albeit the≈øe are the ≈øpeciall things for who≈øe ≈øake men loue this pre≈øent world? After laughing, coms lamenting; after plea≈øure, paine; after pro≈øperitie, mi≈øerie, after delights, torments: if not in this life, yet in the life to come. And therefore what wi≈øe man would loue the world, vnles he will needs be at defiance with God, & lo≈øe his owne ≈øoule?

div.head: 2 The ASSALT giuen by the loue of this pre≈øent WORLD.
div.p:
O Man, ca≈øt thy rouing eies round about th√©e, and take a view of this pre≈øent world, whereof
thou ha≈øt the lord≈øhip & dominion. Looke before th√©e, behind th√©e, aboue th√©e, beneath th√©e, to the right hand, and to the left; and tell me in truth and con≈øcience, if anie thing can be more beautifull, more comelie, more hand≈øome, more louelie, or more delectable, than that which we ≈ø√©e dailie before our face in this life?

O how woonderfull is the glorie of heauen, in the plea≈øant aire, in the light of the Sun, in the increa≈øing & dimini≈øhing of the Moone, in the varietie, cour≈øe, and order of the ≈øtarres? O how comfortable is the earth, with floures of the field and garden, fruits of orchards, plea≈øantnes of medowes, and fre≈øh riuers, plentifulnes of corne, and all kind of graine, fruitfull vines garni≈øhed with leaues and clu≈øters of grapes, woods ca≈øting coole ≈øhadowes from gr√©ene tr√©es; ≈øundrie kinds of creatures ≈øeruing thy v≈øe, as hor≈ø≈øes for riding, kine for milking, hounds for
hunting, ≈øpaniels for hawking, oxen for plowing, a≈ø≈øes and mules for burthen, harts and hinds of the forre≈øt, phea≈øants and peacocks, goodlie birds to behold: hou≈øes hoong about with clothes of arras, wrought roofes, painted walles and ≈øeelings, iuorie beds, couerlets of ≈øilke and n√©edle worke, ≈øh√©etes of the fine≈øt linnen, pillowes of the ≈øofte≈øt downe: great choice of ≈øw√©et mu≈øicke, vpon the organs, the regals, the recorder, the virginals, the timbrell, the citterne, the vials, the cornets, the lute, the harpe, and ≈øundrie ≈øorts of tunable in≈øtruments, y√©elding mo≈øt heauenlie harmonie: maruellous faire, beautifull, gallant, and per≈øonable women, hauing faces, forheads, and eie-browes like gli≈øtering gla≈ø≈øe, eies and ch√©ekes mo≈øt comelie and amorous, lips and chins deintie & delicate, no≈øes and tongues woorth abundance of trea≈øure, neckes and brea≈øts adorned with chaines and ou ‚Ä¢ hes, wri≈øts and fingers decked
with bracelets and rings ≈øet about with pearles and pretious ≈øtones, be≈øides the ine≈øtimable plea≈øures of their neate and fine bodies?

I cannot reckon vp the rich ornaments, and variable recreations of this pre≈øent world, which thou enioie≈øt, O man, after thine owne de≈øire, liuing like an Angell in the midde≈øt of Paradi≈øe, or rather a God in all felicitie and happines. And therefore ≈øet thy heart at re≈øt whiles thou art in the world: thou ha≈øt but a time, ≈øpend it in ≈øuch manner as thou mai≈øt be comforted: for if thou die, there is none of thy pompe will followe th√©e, but thou mu≈øt leaue all behind th√©e.

This is the place where thou mu≈øt build, plant, ≈øet, ≈øowe, graffe, mowe, reape, thre≈øh, grinde, bake, brew, cate, drinke, and make merrie; which I would with th√©e dailie to doo. For after this life, there is none other to be looked for; and how long thou ≈øhalt liue, thou can≈øt not tell: according therefore
to the dominion & lord≈øhip which thou ha≈øt ouer all creatures, command them to ≈øerue th√©e euerie one in their degr√©e, qualitie, and nature.

It is a gr√©efe to th√©e, O man, to lo≈øe that which thou loue≈øt. Ha≈øt thou a tewell of ine≈øtimable value, and exqui≈øite workeman≈øhip? It will gr√©eue thy heart to part from it, either at thy fr√©ends importunate begging, or at thy foes rigorous and violent wre≈øting. Ha≈øt thou a hor≈ø≈øe trained vp for thine owne ≈øaddle and proper riding? Thou wilt be loth to lend him, lea≈øt he mi≈øcarrie, and ≈øo thou ≈øuffer lo≈ø≈øe.

If thy heart be ≈øo fa≈øtened vpon one priuate thing, as a iewell, a hor≈ø≈øe, a ring, a dog (for ≈øometimes thy fan≈øie will be fixed therevpon) that it is a ≈øore vexation and angui≈øh of mind to be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of them, ≈øince they are thy ioie and delight; then it ≈øtandeth with rea≈øon, that the whole world, with all the furniture of the ≈øame, being in thy
po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and winning thine inward affections and outward ≈øen≈øes vnto them, would vtterlie kill and take thy life from th√©e, if thou ≈øhoulde≈øt but a ≈øhort time be forced to take triall of ≈øuch a crooked chance.

And therefore loue the world, and the plea≈øures of the ≈øame; for by them thou mu≈øt be defended from all mi≈øfortunes. It is thy pauilion, thy tent, thy taberuacle; and it is that nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øion, wherewith thou art to be mainteined in the ≈øtate of pro≈øperitie.

div.head: 3 A praier again≈øt the former vice.
div.p:
O Almightie God, the giuer of all goodnes, from whome, as from a full ≈øea, plentifull redemption doth flowe and gu≈øh out mo≈øt ≈øtreminglie; we be≈øeech thee to bow downe thine eies, and to behold vs thy children, liuing among a viperous generation of athei≈øts, epicures,
infidels, and I wot not what workers of iniquitie, who≈øe whole delight is in this world, and the tran≈øitorie vanities of the ≈øame: √¥ giue vs grace to e≈øteeme of it, as it de≈øerueth, yea ≈øo ba≈øelie and homelie to repute of it, as of verie dirt and doong; if for none other cau≈øe but onlie this, which is a cau≈øe of cau≈øes; namelie, for that it is ≈øet vpon mi≈øchiefe and wickednes, giuen to vnrighteou≈ønes and maliciou≈ønes; but chieflie, for that it is at enmitie and ≈øtrife with thee. Thine Apo≈øtle Iames hath taught vs, that to be in amitie and league with the world, to loue it, to delight and take plea≈øure in it, is to be at defiance with thee, √¥ Lord God almightie, to hate thee, to contemne and de≈øpi≈øe thee. And S. Iohn hath told vs, that the world knoweth thee not, nor the true light Chri≈øt Ie≈øus thy ≈øonne, whome thou ≈øente≈øt with ≈øauing helth into the ≈øame, but per≈øecuted the king of glorie, euen to the ≈øhamefull death of the cro≈ø≈øe. Be≈øides
this, we knowe that it is accur≈øed for our ≈øakes, ≈øince our parents Adam & Eue fell from the ≈øtate of innocencie, and committed ≈øinne through pride of mind, which is deliuered and made ouer vnto vs by tradition.

Moreouer, we are taught that the fa≈øhion, the beautie, the loue and glorie of this world vani≈øheth, and all the plea≈øures of the ≈øame peri≈øh. We haue learned that it is to bee con≈øumed and burnt to a≈øhes with fire, and that all the riches, trea≈øures, pompe, pride, renowne, and what≈øoeuer el≈øe it containeth, ≈øhall be conuerted and turned into nothing. Alas then for pitie, that we, whome thou, √¥ Lord, ha≈øt crowned with excellencie aboue all creatures, ≈øhould reioice in a thing of naught, ≈øhould dote and be fond ouer a thing that ≈øhall be wa≈øted in the twinkling of an eie, ≈øhould ≈øet our minds on that, which is cur≈ø≈øed for ≈øin, which is a friend to iniquitie, a foe to innocencie, and to conclude,
a flat enimie to God.

Out alas that we ≈øhould loue that which hateth God and his ≈øonne Chri≈øt, who in the tender bowels of compa≈ø≈øion, was content to be crucified for the world, and yet had not where in the world to laie his head. O mon≈øtrous vnkindnes of the creature to the creator! √¥ vnnaturall dealing! √¥ tiger like crueltie retalied for ≈øuch lamblike lowlines! Grant vs better grace, mo≈øt mercifull father, and ≈øuffer not ≈øathan to ca≈øt ≈øo thicke and darke a mi≈øt of blindnes before our eies, that therby we ≈øhould be allured to loue the world; but rather arme vs with faith whereby wee may ouercome the world, and triumph ouer the ≈øame in victorie, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord, Amen.

div.head: 1 S. BARNARDS golden ≈øentence of the vertue following.
div.p:
THE contempt of this world, √¥ man, if it were common, as it is but rare,
would be a meanes to drawe thee vnto God, and to a longing fo the life to come. Thine owne mi≈øerable and helples estate in this vale of wretchednes, were enough to bring thee to an vtter mi≈øliking and de≈øpi≈øing of this world. For what art thou, √¥ man? no more than a man, yea a bare and naked man, a poore man, and a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed man: a man lamenting that thou art a man, a≈øhamed that thou art borne a naked man, repining that thou art borne to labour, and not to honour: a man borne of a woman, and through the guilt of ≈øin liuing but a while, and therefore fraught with feare, ≈øtuft with mi≈øerie, and wrapped in wo; yea, manie and manie woes, woes of bodie, woes of mind, woes in ≈øleeping, woes in waking, woes on all ≈øides, which way ≈øoeuer thou looke≈øt, and castest thy tooting eies.

How then can≈øt thou find in thy hart, √¥ man, to loue the world; and not rather to hate and haue it in contempt, knowing that it is the fornace where all the≈øe afflictions are forged? Thou art one of Adams ≈øonnes, de≈øcended of his loines, borne in ≈øin, brought vp in wickednes; and therefore
thou canst not liue in this world without labour, without ≈øorowe, without angui≈øh, without misfortune, and infinite ca≈øualties day by day ebbing and flowing, wherevnto thou art ≈øo much the more ≈øubiect, bicau≈øe thou loue≈øt the world, which thou oughte≈øt to contemne, and vtterlie mi≈ølike. Againe, in louing the world, thou art in league with ≈øin, and in fee with death. Why then wilt thou loue the world? why wilt thou de≈øire his friend≈øhip? why wilt thou hunt after the delight of the ≈øame? the longer thou liue≈øt in it, the greeuou≈øer is thy tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, the heinou≈øer thy wickednes, the more in number thine offences. Loue this world the le≈ø≈øe, and ≈øin the le≈ø≈øe: contemne this world the more, and ri≈øe to righteou≈ønes the more: for the killing of the one, is the quickning of the other. Set not thy mind, √¥ man, vpon this pre≈øent wicked world, nor the vaine pomps and tran≈øitorie tri≈øhtra≈øh of the ≈øame; for it ≈øhall waxe old as a garment, and all the beautifull brauerie thereof ≈øhall vade like a blo≈ø≈øome.

Looke aloft, √¥ man, to Ieru≈øalem the citie of the great king, who will ≈øatisfie thee
with the fine≈øt floure of wheate, and cheri≈øh thee with comfortable ≈øtreames of running riuers. There is no mea≈øure nor weight, there is no ≈øcale nor ballance, there are no bounds nor marks; but plentie and abundance, fulnes and ≈øtore, freedome and libertie. There is no feare nor trembling, becau≈øe God hath establi≈øhed peace in his kingdome; no enimie entreth in, no friend goeth out of that citie: there are no temptations; there are no trouble≈øome thoughts; becau≈øe he that is alwaies one, and neuer changeth, hath ≈øet euerie thing in a ≈øtedfa≈øt and inuariable order. There is no power of tempting, no cau≈øe of di≈øquieting, no ablenes of hurting, no dooing again≈øt gods holie will, and no tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing; but happie peace, and peaceable happines; perfect plea≈øure, and plea≈øant perfectnes; one will in God and vs, ≈øo that what≈øoeuer plea≈øeth him, the ≈øame plea≈øeth vs. There is cleere light, which wee ≈øhall behold with cleere eies. There is the ≈øouereigne good, euen the trea≈øure of trea≈øures, which we ≈øhall not onlie ≈øee, but al≈øo enioie, I meane life euerlasting, which is the fulnes of time, the length of daies, yea,
the true daie, which knoweth no ≈øun ≈øetting, the high noonetide, the abundance of perfect glorie, euerlasting truth, and true euerlastingnes.
